items.title: Olympic curling controversy takes aim at Canada
Olympic viewing guide Day 10: More Canadian gold on the way?
items.summary_auto: CBC Sports' daily Olympics newsletter previews the Canadian medal chances coming up on Monday after Mikael Kingsbury broke the ice with Canada's first gold of the Games.

items.title: Weeks after Toronto’s record snowfall, some residents are still struggling to use sidewalks
items.summary_auto: Some residents are still struggling to get by as snow clearing efforts continue three weeks after Toronto’s record-breaking snowfall.

items.title: Skaters Stellato-Dudek and Deschamps hoping for one more comeback after 'remarkable recovery' from injury
items.summary_auto: Canadian world champion Deanna Stellato-Dudek spoke about her recovery from injury, after a disappointing Olympic pairs short program performance that left her and partner Maxime Deschamps in 14th place.

items.title: 'He was a man on a mission': Activist Eddie Carvery remembered for keeping memory of Africville, N.S., alive
items.summary_auto: Eddie Carvery, the activist who lived in a trailer on the site of the former town of Africville for over 50 years, has died. Carvery used his decades-long protest to call for reparations for the former residents of the town.

items.title: Victim. Survivor. Icon. Gisèle Pelicot has heard it all. But in her words? She's ‘an optimist'
DNA recovered from glove found near home of Savannah Guthrie's missing mom: FBI
items.summary_auto: The FBI says a glove containing DNA was found about three kilometres from Nancy Guthrie's home and appears to match those worn by a masked person outside her front door in Tucson, Ariz., the night she vanished.

items.title: 'It was a gift': French goalie Junca's birthday was a memorable one despite 10-2 loss to Canadian stars
items.summary_auto: Imagine, for a few horrifying moments, that you have woken up as Julian Junca, the starting goalie for France. It’s your birthday. You have just turned 28. And you are facing Canada in Olympic hockey.

items.title: Patrick Chan, Kurt Browning relive Olympic heartbreak after Malinin collapse
items.summary_auto: Patrick Chan and Kurt Browning, two Canadian figure skating legends, watched with the rest of the sporting world in astonishment as the American star crashed under pressure, tumbling to eighth after a disastrous free skate.

items.title: It's been 58 years since it last took Canada this long to win Winter Olympics gold
items.summary_auto: It took nine days before a Canadian athlete won a gold medal at the 2026 Milano-Cortina Olympics — the longest the country has ever taken to win gold at the Winter Games in 58 years.

items.title: Man and woman arrested after flooding at Winnipeg police headquarters
items.summary_auto: A man and a woman are facing mischief charges connected to flooding at the Winnipeg police headquarters that left extensive damage still being cleaned up.

items.title: Israel fires deadly airstrike at Gaza tent camp, Palestinian officials say
items.summary_auto: Israel fired airstrikes across the Gaza Strip on Sunday, killing at least 11 people, Palestinian officials said, in what the military called a response to ceasefire violations by Palestinian militant group Hamas.

items.title: Gisèle Pelicot has been called a lot of things: Victim. Survivor. Icon. She calls herself 'an optimist'
items.summary_auto: Gisèle Pelicot waived her right to anonymity at her ex-husband's trial in September 2024, where he would be convicted of drugging her, raping her and inviting men to do the same while she was unconscious. Now, she's telling her wider story in a memoir as she rebuilds her life.

items.title: Ukrainian drone damages Russian Black Sea port ahead of U.S.-brokered peace talks
items.summary_auto: A Ukrainian drone strike ignited fires at one of Russia’s Black Sea ports, officials said on Sunday, ahead of fresh talks aimed at ending the nearly four-year-old war.

items.title: Zoinks! Regina woman turns love of Scooby-Doo into collecting and podcasting
items.summary_auto: Visitors to Alexa Lawlor's Regina home can't miss noticing her extensive Scooby-Doo memorabilia collection when they walk into her living room.

items.title: Stompin' Tom fans push Saint John council for statue of Canadian icon
items.summary_auto: Saint John resident Greg Hemmings and his friends are advocating for a statue to honor Canadian music icon Stompin' Tom Connors on the city's waterfront.

items.title: The long, cold, sometimes deadly way N.B.ers used to travel in winter
items.summary_auto: Long before studded tires and heated seats, New Brunswickers relied on horse-drawn sleighs to get around in the winter.

items.title: London veteran gives Canada’s flag a voice on Flag Day
items.summary_auto: A London, Ont., veteran who witnessed Canada's maple leaf flag rise for the first time in 1965 is marking its 61st anniversary with a unique tribute: a letter written from the flag's perspective.

items.title: One year later, crews continuing to monitor grounded MSC Baltic III
items.summary_auto: The MSC Baltic III has been pounded by winter weather and winds in recent months, and officials working on the site say there's still uncertainty around the vessel a year after it was grounded on the west coast of Newfoundland.

items.title: How a history of stigma still deters some Black Quebecers from donating blood
items.summary_auto: Policies dating back to the 1980s likely still play a role in the distrust some in Quebec's Black communities feel toward donating blood, but people like Stanley Étienne, working with Héma-Québec, strive to encourage more people to look past that history to save lives today.

items.title: The night intruders broke into my home was the night that sent me to Canada
items.summary_auto: Ope Michael had a good life in Nigeria, but his sense of safety was shattered the night intruders broke into his home. That was the moment he decided to move to Canada, experiencing both the highs and lows of restarting life in a new country.

items.title: The art of no deal: A Greenlandic carver’s vengeful response to Trump shows opportunity amid crisis
items.summary_auto: Greenlanders don't think that Donald Trump is done with their island quite yet, but some are determined to make the most of the crisis. Carver Kim Kleist-Eriksen — who carved his own rebuttal of Trump's efforts to take over the island — has found new audiences for his art in Canada; tourism operators are dealing with a surge of international interest;   and those who want Greenland's independence from Denmark see opportunities to forge stronger international bonds.

items.title: Tourism was once an 'economic locomotive' in Cuba. Now, the train is coming off the tracks
items.summary_auto: For decades, Cuba's tourism sector has enjoyed a reputation as an "economic locomotive" among authorities who saw it as the lifeblood of the Caribbean island country's economy. But the industry has been in decline since its 2018 peak, and the U.S. government squeezing Cuba's oil supply has pushed the nation's most crucial industry closer to its breaking point.

items.title: Ottawa sees 'huge opportunity' as trade delegation heads to Mexico, says cabinet minister
items.summary_auto: A Canadian trade mission to Mexico this week could produce new deals by early spring, and marks the country's "most significant" such mission ever to Mexico, according to Canada-U.S. Trade Minister Dominic LeBlanc.
